comments.commentBody:
and Elke

YIKES- I KANT remember that I ever ATE just one LATKE......
Cincy actually sold that game out. Driving rainstorms tend to put a damper on attendance.

the AAC is a Frankenstein monster built to chase the football money dream. The conference stretches from CT to FL to TX. UConn had to travel to Florida for the AAC tournament. Their game against Cinny was played in a stadium that was 1/3 full. Its a shame. It would be great if they could come back to the Big East and focus on basketball.
Notre Dame did not betray any association nor did it violate any agreement by signing with NBC. Your assertion is false.

The reason that UConn has little success in football is that northeasterners don't follow them.  The most popular college team in New York City is Notre Dame, which happens to be in Indiana.  If fans don't care, they won't support a local team.  That is UConn's fate.  A premier program would exist if the fans cared.  And folks who think that makes northeasterners high-minded don't know what this is really about.  UConn has no football rivalries, it's got no history of success, and it exists in an area where three  prominent NFL teams are all well-supported.  The northeast is big football country, it just isn't college football country.

UConn belongs in the ACC. Big East is now all private Catholic universities (except Butler, which is also Christian). Big 12 is absurd, geographically, and UConn has almost nothing in common culturally with schools like Iowa State, Baylor, and TCU. What would make the most sense is to pair it with another AAC school, say Memphis, and expand the ACC to 16 schools and 2 8-school divisions for football. But since everything about conference expansion has made no sense lately, that probably won't happen...
As always, it's a MONEY problem... What happens with the 'Student-Athlete'?

As a Syracuse grad, i would love to see our old nemesis and rival, UCONN, in the ACC. It would give SU, Pitt, and BC a northern rival, which is desperately needed in this southeast-focused league. It would bring the best basketball program in the east into the league and it would just make the ACC a better conference. The powers that be in the ACC need to find a way to get the Huskies into this league and soon.

I think Nocera overstates the importance of AAU membership in determining the Big Ten'seconds choice of Rutgers over UConn, and mistakenly implies that they are both in the New York media market.  Nebraska had already been kicked out of the AAU before the Big Ten offered membership to Rutgers, so that cannot be a deciding factor. What was a deciding factor was the fact that Rutgers is in the NYC media market and UCONN is not, allowing the Big Ten Network to negotiate capitation rates for including the channel in cable and dish packages in the greater NYC area. That's a lot harder argument to make with UCONN.

UConn’s "Ambitions"?

Basketball, football... what about academics? Isn't UConn supposed to be a place whose main "ambition" is education? Oh right sorry--I forgot that sort of thing is passe...
Joe you just can't stop hating Notre Dame, can you? Betrayal? More like acumen.

The primary reason the football stadium is not on campus is the roads. It would be gridlock for every football game. The folks who live in the area (Mansfield and Coventry) were opposed to widening the roads.

I did my Masters (1985) at UConn and remember Cliff Robinson shooting foul shots in the field house.  There were no facilities.  Since then, only magic - and most of it basketball magic.  The football program is a joke.  Rentschler Field was built 25 miles from campus in East Hartford of all places - so depressing - so it wasn't for the students.  As with most things in childhood (and college is part of childhood), once the adults and boosters got involved, they have done their best to ruin the university experience.  Still UConn basketball is an amazing thing.  Rejoin the Big East and let the magic continue!  Go Huskies!

The basis of your logic is not sound.  Rutgers made its way into the Big 10 with a historically weak football program.  The driving factor was access to a lucrative media market.  Connecticut offers very lucrative media market in terms of size and demographics.  Abandoning football would be nonsensical and would forfeit any chance for P5 entry and the economic benefits that follow.  UConn is not some sleepy old Yankee Conference school.  It is a top 20 national university, and it will find a spot in the Big 10 unless the Big 12 grabs it sooner.  The market is simply to attractive to ignore, and the school is academically superior.  The only question will be whether the Big 10 recognizes that by taking UConn they preemptively lock up the Northeast.
Wow!  Here I thought Usada was a typo. (-;

I don't see the point in trying to control it. I think transparency is a good idea, so active tests that show who's using and who aren't. Those not using and beating out those who are using will stand out even more. It'll work itself out in the end. As for those using will live less...this doesn't really bother me. It is a personal choice issue if one would like to use.

lou andrews; I don't like Clinton. Sanders I think is the most trustworthy but he won't win the primary. Trump there is a benefit if he does win office in that congress will hate him so much that both parties would unite to override vetoes. This could lead to some powers that were expanded under Bush and Obama to be taken away. This would a be a good thing to reign in executive orders that both parties have abused..it's a gamble but I'm willing to take that gamble. So yes I will be voting for Trump in the general; do I support any of his policies..absolutely not. I support open borders; no borders ideally and think immigrants are vital to any country with an aging population. But..at the time it would be nice to see presidential powers curtailed some, if anyone could get congress to unite to accomplish such..it would but Trump.

As for cheating; well as mentioned earlier in this reply I want transparency so we know who uses and who does not however we do not ban them. Applaud those that outperform the users; it'll fix itself.

I won't bother making assumptions about you..to me that's childish.

On its face, this might seem sensible. But, think again. Suppose an athlete were taking drugs for bipolar disorder, depression, to decrease cravings for alcohol? Or for another disorder the acknowledgement of which the athlete does not owe the public? Do we want athletes not to seek treatment for disorders that carry some kind of stigma? Not all athletes are millionaires like Sharapova. Do you really think a journeyman minor leaguer who may never make it to the big leagues owes the public this information? How about a college athlete?

If the meds the the athletes are taking are accurately reported to sports authorities that should be enough.

ST, suppose that the doctor concludes that her complaints are due to over exhaustion caused by training at a level her body cannot sustain. Then if meldonium allows her to continue, then it is indeed a performance enhancing drug. But as long as it is not banned, one cannot object to this on ethical grounds any more than a tennis player who repeatedly needs knee surgery or other treatments.

You can well imagine that the WADA could impose limits on the number of sports related surgeries you can have in some time frame and still be allowed to compete. The whole point of the anti doping regulations is to make sure people who have a body physique that just isn't good enough should not patch up their bodies using nontrivial medical interventions in order to be able to compete.

Finesse and artistry, yes, but athleticism has not been eliminated from the game. I would argue that the technologies have enabled brute athleticism to dominate the game. Especially women's tennis, which is a boring baseline game waiting for an unforced error.
I'm aware of Google.  The NYT ought to provide a bit of background in its articles.  Otherwise, this article is nothing more than celebrity gossip-news.

It's an over the counter drug that has been legal for 40 years. Don't need a doctors prescription, go, ask, get.

To ban it because a bunch of Russians use it, without any clarity of whether and how it works is a bit fanatical. Russians are superstitious people. Maybe they take it for placebo effect?

It whiffs of politics.

Wonderful, wonderful, wonderful, Sean.

In this era of hate, anger, and intolerance, you're setting a beautiful example of love, kindness, caring and inclusion. Keep going, pal...

Let's see how long that "one of the guys" attitude lasts in LA if he does become a star.

Keeping him away from the Kardashians would be a good start.

and Elke
John- your avatar is a landsman of XWP's favourite punster. His name goes with today's theme . His (original) name is MORE valuable than IRONWOOD.
I don't know whether he liked to take things slow (LARGO).
Husam and I are still friends and stay in contact since we met on lesbos last summer :) no need to lose the faith yet in communication and friendship across countries, languages and cultures

Most of us don't have IDs or can't get one for one reason or another....... but i was working and still homeless and eating out of dumpsters, and ive been to college..... so u should direct your anger elsewhere or ask before u judge

As a dirty kid myself, i can answer this..., most of us clean up.... there is a code in a way that says don't ruin a place for the next kids....,, but if we are at a hop out and our train is sided for a minute, we usually don't take the time to pick up everything
